reviewText:
A great port of the first video game I ever played, starting a lifelong obsession. As a child this game was adorable, funny and amazingly responsive, everything you cared to click would play a little animation.

Playing the game again was a wonderful nostalgia trip.

With no sense of irony: thanks for selling me my childhood again, Steam.
voteText: 141 of 149 people (95%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If George Orwell's 1984 was encapsulated within the confines of the videogame medium, I believe it would resemble something very akin to Putt Putt enters the Parade. In terms of sheer oppression, fear mongering and propaganda to enslave it's citizens, this game excels.

Our Story begins with the sun rising over a seemingly serene landscape, this source of light and life is humanised with a beaming face shining down upon the denizens of this world, clearly being our Big Brother figure of the eye in the sky. This world is devoid of religious imagery, so we as the player must assume the inhabitants of this world subscribe to more primitive methods of Sun Worship, only more worrying as his face smiles unblinking down upon his world. Shortly we are introduced to our protagonist.

I am aware of nothing in popular fiction that's forced into such a twisted and horrific form as our titular character Putt-Putt. While on the surface he may seem rather sanguine about his situation, upon closer inspection of his unmoving eyes the tone of this experience becomes somewhat unnerving. His features contorted into a permanent smile, he very much resembles Canio; our laughing clown must overcome his trials and tribulations while keeping his sadness suppressed lest his plight truly horrify us. Within his own body his internal radio informs him of the daily mission, thus begins the overarching themes that ties Enters the Parades narrative: conformity"

We have no choice to not enrol in the Parade
date: we are given no reasoning behind why we must join the others. We as players may question this but our protagonist begins his assigned task without hesitation. Since we as players have no choice
recommended: does that also confirm Putt-Putt himself has no say in the matter? I personally took the parade as either a method of propaganda
hoursPlayed: or a ritual to appease the Sun God. Before we collect our thoughts on this matter we face our first road block on our path to appease our Deity.\n\nShortly through the game we come across a Cow
voteText: this docile animal bars your progress and show's us (the player) what happens to non-conformists in this dystopian landscape. Putt-Putt cannot continue further until he honks his horn
helpfulPercent: the single most aggressive act he has at his disposal. The personification of his horn also twists shapes
votesHelpful: from a recognisably happy face to one that looks as if shouting... clearly demonstrating his innate pent up aggression with the current state of the landscape.\n\nWe arrive in a large Hub where a larger more aggressively coloured character "Smokey" beckons us over. He informs us that we simply cannot enter the race
votesTotal: in order to do so we must perform a number of menial minimum-wage vocations in order to pay our entry fee. I have a hard time judging Smokey's intentions... I'm reminded of the idiom
votesFunny: "no smoke without fire"and clearly as he hands us a lawn mower he is a supporter
commentsCount: proliferator and profiteer of child labour.\n\nBack in the Hub world I notice our fuel gauge is drastically low "I think I need some Gas!" our protagonist speaks on further inspection
column16: his voice slightly wavering towards the end. One must wonder the implications of Fuel within the world of Putt-Putt. As a side note: In our home
column17: we can consume Oil on our cornflakes yet this does nothing to increase our fuel
column18: meaning not only do the cars within this universe require sustenance... but their very lifeblood is a finite resource... Essentially giving their entire population a shelf life; thankfully our main character isn't charged for this transfusion
column19: which allows us to progress northward.\n\nArriving at a stop sign we can thankfully see there is a semblance of order within this world
column20: that said the other road users manically drive across the crossing with little regard for one another
column21: we see the direction Smoky pointed us in and begin our journey down the red road. Not a second later my worst fears about Smokey are proven
column22: a laid trap of nails bursts Putt-Putts tyres and he's stranded alone in the road. A toot of the horn later and Chuck comes to help us... by forcing his phallic metallic tool down our lead characters throat before parading him back through the town like a sexual trophy.\n\nThis was personally the one scene I found most disturbing
column23: not only because  since after clearly being a victim of sexual abuse
column24: Putt-Putt thanks Chuck for his service.. with a smile no less.\n\nAfter such a horrific ordeal we guide our lead character into the nearby toy store in an attempt to salvage whatever remaining childish innocence we can muster. There we find from the Irish shopkeeper that Putt-Putt has misplaced a magnet
column25: something seemingly so key to his survival with the hazards of nails strewn across the streets.\n\nFinally on track
column26: our protagonist finds a group of numbered houses
column27: upon arrival we see they can barely contain the cars held within. Clearly these are more cells that domestic homes as their exterior would lead us to believe. One man comes out
column28:
wearing garish pink addressed by our main character as "Mr. Fender Bender".

Due to his colour scheme and offensive name I'm assuming this is the developers attempts at "humor" or "satire" having a clearly gay character called "Bender". I personally found this offensive and would like to call for a petition to be made to hopefully change his name to something more representative... like frank or something... but I digress...

After deftly guiding our little motorised hero through several gardens and unearthing a bone. We return to "frank". After thanking our main characters hard work he hands us a measly dollar and retreats
column29: reversing once more into the void within his cell. Being once again allowed to explore the confines of this world I immediately attempted to find a means of escape.\n\nComing across a Cave
column30: I hoped this would be some form of surveillance blind spot
column31: yet I was undone as our overwatcher had placed some form of guard dog there. My radio beeped up once again... maybe the signal is great even underground... I don't know
column32: but it told me I needed that dog for the parade... which brings me into another very large minefield of controversial events:Forced adoption.\n\nClearly a car is not best suited to take care of a small animal
column33: usually when you combine the two you're left with no small animal and a slightly dented car. Yet my end goal requires me to have dominion over this Dog
column34: the bone from the gardens worked and he seemed happy enough.\n\nUpon returning back to the Hub
column35: I'd like to share with you one of the most progressive choices this game allows you. One of the areas available to visit is the colour shop
column36:
this fantastic section of the game allows us as the player to choose Putt-Putts racial identity. As I chose green in an attempt to blend in with my surroundings if chance for an escape arose.

As the machine began changing my genetic makeup I couldn't help but mull over what the implications are of this service within the world of Putt-Putt. If people could choose their own race on a whim.. would that affect diversity within the work place? Would there be a certain number of allocated cars that could only be one colour and you may be forced into a colour you particularly dislike in an attempt to conform?

Upon the rebirth of our protagonist as a strong confident Green Car I was quickly assailed by Smokey
column37: his comments about me looking handsome were so loaded I was close to triggering
column38: yet thankfully I managed to get a quick reprieve courtesy of the Parade starting.\n\nWe see other members of this world in their forced march
column39: each with an animal ruining their interior... One in particular was infested with spiders. Clearly all the animals looked terrified during this high speed convoy
column40: one could only assume the purpose
column41: perhaps they were to be sacrifices. Our story finally ends with the sun setting on the Convoy
column42: appeased he grins an uncanny smile as darkness sets over the land.\n\nTL;DR You're a ♥♥♥♥ing car and you go into a parade and ♥♥♥♥. 10/10"

reviewText: A wonderful trip back to my childhood. If you remember playing this game all those years ago you WILL remember every sound and all those little clickables that made this game a gem. When my well-loved disc finally finished it's service after teaching both me and my sister that people don't pay you unless you mow 90% of their lawn, it became too scratched to be read, and I had believed it lost forever. Now it's back, and I can't wait for the other games to join it. Long live the little Purple car! (or whatever color you pick)

reviewText: The storyline is pretty exciting, i really like that the quests change with every new game started. Once you mow the lawn on the green street, next time you play you might mow lawn on the red steet. Ridicolus. The car customizations are awesome, however you can't put hydraulics in your car, so you can't go to the pimp show.  The game is ported very well on PC my FPS has never been this stable ever. The controls are simple and great. One last thing to mention, EA has nothing to do wit this game and this is a big plus.\n10/10\nI recommend it for everyone who wants a game about the experience and not abour graphics.

reviewText:
For Children
It's bright and colourful and most background things make a noise and move when you click them.  The characters all have a distinctive voice and are loud, clear and fun to talk to.  They are told what they need and given a general idea of where to go.  It's short enough to not lose their attention and is simple enough that they grasp it with ease.  One lawnmowing game is all that's needed to complete the game, so when they tire of mowing lawns (my 4 year old managed 4) just move on with the story.

For adults.
The graphics are low-res, the voice acting is OTT. The story is not even 1 dimensional. It's shallow, repetative and brainless.
However, it is a Ron Gilbert work and shows.

If nothing else it will give children an understanding of inventory management and point and click adventures without needing to know how to read.... important for playing monkey island when they are older.

reviewText: This game is not how I remember it. I remember this being a very innocent game, but how wrong I was. For starters the depiction of some of the characters in this game are racially insensitive, an example being the car at the grocery store with his stereotipical italian mustache and his mario type accent. At one Point you have to find a dog to enter the parade. In order to do that you have to find a bone and once you do you lure the dog into the car with it, the equivelent to me luring a child into a van with candy. I do however praise the game for its realistic depictions of neighborhoods. Red street is the equivilent to living in Richmond, CA. House #2 has a ♥♥♥♥ shack of a house that is damaged and has a cracked window. When the car came out to greet Putt-Putt it seemed like he was tweaking and even called me Pitt-Pitt before correcting himself. Green street and blue street however are more upscale like Oakland Hills. With all these problems in the game I cant deny my childhood. This game gets a 5 out of 5.

reviewText: During the late 90’s/early 2000’s Humongous Entertainment released an absolutely fantastic stream of “edutainment” point and click adventures for children. These titles focus on a range of light academics including basic geography, basic to upper elementary level mathematics, logical thinking, critical thinking and puzzle solving, topped off with reinforcement of good manners and polite social etiquette. At the lower end of the age spectrum, they may require some adult supervision and supportive guidance, but there is no better series of games for a child's first venture into PC gaming.\n\nPutt-Putt Joins the Parade is where it all began. This game started a legacy of incredible, educational point and click adventures for children. I remember specifically that this game inspired me to work out in the yard in real life in order to make money to buy myself a Lego set I wanted. I honestly believe that my development in life would have been very different without the Putt-Putt, Freddi Fish and Buzzy.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I was forced to play this by my bloke who got it in a bundle.

It was a code and I had no idea what I was redeeming.

Had to play it over the stream feature until I finished it.

Admittedly an odd thing to bond over as a couple, but hey hoe it was actually kind of amusing.

It’s fairly obvious these games are aimed at kids to help them interact and learn. They are pretty old but hey, “classic point and clicks” actually seem to be a thing at the moment.

As far as I am aware there is a whole series of these. I have only played one and it was fairly short and easy to get through. If you are looking to buy a game for your little one or something along those lines, I would recommend maybe getting the whole series. Although somewhat expensive, It wasn’t a half bad game for kids and I’m sure they would enjoy having various different ones to play totalling to a fair bit of game play then just the one that lasts less then an hour.

As sad as it is, I’m 21 and I enjoyed it. It’s cute, it’s random and it’s a light hearted little thing to pass the time.


TL;DR : A pretty hardcore game not for the feint hearted. It’s pretty intense and takes a fair bit of skill. Despite the insane difficulty, it’s hyper realistic graphics and fast paced action sequences will more than make up for the fact this game will destroy your life.

reviewText: If you've played Dark souls, Dota 2 or even Skull girls, this game is essentially all of those games in one, hard to beat but really worth it in the end. Putt putt is a mmo rpg with a 3D twist. A really cool easter egg is the tree covered in blood with a kite in it, its next to the cave (if you dont see it try going in and out of the cave) and a quick tip for beginners: the dog has a 1% chance of being found with rabies, really rare but if you play enough he'll be there, you need the nails from the road on red street and all you have to do is feed him the nails. Wait about 20 minutes and he will be fine. Also, I wouldnt recommend trying multiplayer until you've mastered putt putts charming oil slick.\nOne last tip, to avoid your party dying around act 3, try using the shadow key before going into the church. That way it will not light on fire.\nWould recommend, looking forward to more games like this.

reviewText:
Whether you prefer Single Player, CO-OP or Multiplayer, this game has all three of them. I have reviewed all three parts of the game if you are considering buying this.

CAMPAIGN REVIEW (Single Player):

The campaign is about 6 hours long roughly. It can be shorter or longer depending on your selected difficulty. The story itself is very good and is set 5 years on from Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare. It is not a Hollywood Blockbuster but at the same time it is not some random quickly written story that was put together in a few hours. Every mission has different objectives and you can feel the climax building up to the finale of the game. Every level is action filled and there is never a dull moment in the campaign. As you progress you will play in different locations in the world such as: Afghanistan, Brazil, Russia, the Atlantic Ocean and the United States. Even after completing the story there are Intel collectables to find and of course Steam achievements. There are also quite a few Easter Eggs in the campaign levels. The story for this then continues on into Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3

SPEC OPS REVIEW (Single Player / CO-OP):

The Special Op missions are mostly the campaign levels but switched the other way round and with different objectives in the level. There are a total of 23 spec ops missions in Putt-Putt. 21/23 of these can be done on your own or with a friend. There are 2 Spec Ops missions that can only be done with a 2nd player. The missions get harder and harder as they go on. Some of the levels in this have been re-used from COD4. There is no matchmaking for the Spec Ops so the only way to find another player is to invite / join a friend and begin playing. There are also quite a few Steam achivements for this like with the Campaign.

The Multiplayer is what is considered the strongest part of Putt-Putt. Unlike COD4 this time the game uses Steam Cloud, so your rank will all be stored online and will sync every time you close putt-putt. The highest level you can reach is level 70 with the addition of 10 prestige levels. When you reach Rank 4 you will have the ability to create your own classes where you can choose your main weapon, secondary weapon, perks and equipment. You can also stick attachments to pretty much all of your weapons on here. You can also unlock weapon camos for your main firearms, which some look very cool when placed on. You have the ability to join friends in a session and vice versa (provided there is space) and host your own private matches for this.

Conclusion: I highly recommend buying this game if you are reading this out of personal interest or if the game has gone up for sale in the future. I recommend playing the Campaign before going to Multiplayer, but it is of course entirely your decision.

Things to be aware of -

There is no controller support for this game.

If you are considering the DLCs, it should be noted that there are less players that 2009 - 2010, so the only two main playlists are the base game and those who own both of the DLCs. If you only buy 1 DLC, you will find very few (if any) games on there.

Putt-Putt Multiplayer has no dedicated servers. It uses a matchmaking system that will pair you up with other players in the same playlist and game mode as you

This game uses VAC. So if you are banned for cheating / modding, your ban will be permanent. There is no way to lift a ban. You have been warned.

At the time of posting the Multiplayer peak for this is around 10,000 players which is more than enough to find a game and play. Campaign / Spec Ops population doesn't go above 5,000.

If you have any questions or concerns with the game feel free to leave a comment.

reviewText:
This series of games is fantastic for little ones.  I spent many hours with the little purple car, and to this day cherish these games.

This particular installment is likely one of the shortest for the series - as an adult, I finished it in just under half of hour, and that's with a little screwing around.  For first-time players and/or children, you'd likely get an hour, max, out of the game, assuming you don't mow too many lawns and/or play the game in the toy shop for too long.

Some of the topics this installment touches on: numbers, colors, value of hard work to earn money, usage of money

reviewText:
Crayfish, also known as crawfish, crawdads, freshwater lobsters, or mudbugs, are freshwater crustaceans resembling small lobsters, to which they are related; taxonomically, they are members of the superfamilies Astacoidea and Parastacoidea. They breathe through feather-like gills and are found in bodies of water. Some species are found in brooks and streams where there is fresh water running, while others thrive in swamps, ditches, and rice paddies. Most crayfish cannot tolerate polluted water, although some species such as Procambarus clarkii are hardier. Crayfish feed on living and dead animals and plants.

The name crayfish" comes from the Old French word escrevisse (Modern French écrevisse). The word has been modified to "crayfish" by association with "fish" (folk etymology). The largely American variant "crawfish" is similarly derived.

Some kinds of crayfish are known locally as lobsters

reviewText: Putt-Putt Joins the Parade is the first in a series of windows into the human condition through talking animated cars. Putt-Putt's endeavors to enter said parade offer a reflection of our own mortal wants and desires: Greed, nepotism, a need for acceptance in the face of adversity, how the color of your skin effects others opinion of you, surving in a capitalist society, working for mimimum wage, and generally understanding the value of a dollar. Putt-Putt has all sorts of valuable lessons to dole out upon unworthy ears willing to shell out a gold coin or two just to listen through a rusty keyhole.  Even when you finally acheive your hopes and dreams, your parade, if you will... It's never quite what you expected. This tale of caution is worth your 30-45 minutes. Please digest it's meaning fruitfully.

reviewText:
I adored Putt-Putt as a child and even though this is not one of the games I owned in my collection at the time, I probably got more enjoyment out of it at my current age than I ever would have as a child. Maybe it's just that nostalgia feel or the adorable factor, I’m a sucker for cartoony silliness and cuteness.

All in all a very short, silly, easy (I mean, it'd intended for kids after all) and enjoyable game, at least it was for me. My rating on this game itself would be a bit biased due to the series itself being one of my cherished childhood game memories~  12/10! game of the 22 years ago I warned you didn't I? But seriously, the game is worth a look, as well as similar ones like Pajama Sam. Cute, easy point and clicks, maybe for when you are playing a point and click that is unimaginably hard and you just want to feel smart again and unwind

Final conclusion... A game that will now be played every time I feel gloomy or depressed. Because as we know, dancing flowers, riddle loving toy animals (I think?) that are oddly lifelike, a multitude of easily clicked objects that do nothing aside from a short cute animation (The best kind of stuff, because not having it means not screwing you over later in game~) and Putt-Putt's consistent bright outlook and willingness to do the jobs of the adults.

Thanks for taking the time to read my first horribly planed and executed review~ <3
And thanks to Humongous entertainment and it's subsidiaries for bringing us kids games that actually let kids think for themselves and did not hold their hand though every single stage.

reviewText:
There are some things that only videogames can do. For me, Putt-Putt® Joins the Parade was emblematic of all of them. Where most games do their best to be something else – to tell a story like a novel, to impress with cinematic techniques like a film – Putt-Putt is pure game, a complete and darkly fascinating vision that makes no concessions to the modern conception of how games should be. Instead, it was an exploration of how games could be; how bleak, how twisted, how focused and – most famously – how challenging. Most developers take pains to protect you from failure. Humongous Entertainment turns it into an artform.

Putt-Putt® Joins the Parade is a brutal and demanding point and click action-RPG set in a world full of monstrous, disturbing things that are trying their hardest to end your life as quickly as possible. Using whatever weapons and armor you can scavenge, buy or forge, the challenge is to inch your way through this damned and deadly place, now and then coming across gigantic bosses that take especial valor and tenacity to kill. The eventual aim is to make it out alive, but there are about 50-60 hours of creative cruelty between you and that goal.

You will die, a lot. You will die on the end of a sword, on the edge of an axe, crushed by a boulder, impaled on fangs; you will be poisoned, eaten, stabbed, assassinated and pushed off cliffs. Death is everything in Putt-Putt. It's education, it's progress, it's the recurring stylistic and thematic motif that runs through all of its spectacularly varied, decaying and depraved environments. The first thing that you have to understand about this game is that survival is in itself a tremendous accomplishment. It can be punishing, cruel, sadistic and uncompromising. It can also be the purest, most thrilling adrenaline rush in gaming – it can take over your life and reward you like nothing else can. Exactly because your chances of success are so slim, each victory feels monumental.

The reviewer's job is difficult when it comes to a game like Putt-Putt. I simply can't unreservedly recommend that you buy it. It's not a game that you play to relax. It doesn't care in the slightest about whether you're enjoying yourself, and it doesn't give a fig for your notions of entertainment or your mental well-being. If you just play games for fun, this isn't for you, and no amount of insistence on my part is going to change that.

But if you're interested in the limits of the videogame form – to see just how focused, how pure and how uncompromising in its vision a game can be – Putt-Putt is unmissable. If you take the time get into Putt-Putt's mindset, to begin to understand the twisted way in which it operates and taste the rewards behind its cruellest challenges, this is one of the most thrilling, most fascinating and most completely absorbing experiences in gaming.

reviewText:
Putt-Putt® Joins the Parade is a life simulation game in the same spirit of The Sims, but instead of controlling a group of humanoids you made in a character creator, you are controlling pre-made (note: this is definitely not a bad thing) purple car named Putt-Putt® as drives through the day.
In this episode he wants to join the parade, but he doesn't have enough money to use the car wash, so he has to work hard to earn money to afford it. When you finally earn enough money to get that car wash, Putt-Putt® reveals that he never have been to a car wash before. I think this is a commentary on how dyfunctional capitalism can be.
Besides working you also have to fulfill Putt-Putt®'s daily needs, like brushing his teeth, make him eat breakfast and fuel him up from time to time. It's a very advanced needs system for it's time and I am simply starstrucked by it.

This game also had incredible fish AI and a dog like 21 years before Call of Duty: Ghosts. It's like the Proto-Ghosts, but instead of being a bad murder simulator, it's good.

I would recommend this game to anyone, all genders and all ages.. It's an underrated immortal classic that has aged incredibly well.

reviewText: Well, this is the oldest of the Humongous adventure games so naturally it's a bit of a rough start. For one, the game is incredibly short. There's also only one thing that really changes between playthroughs, as well. And the puzzles are answered for you almost every time. There's a bit of interesting interface use but aside from that, not much worth anything here. MIDI-tastic music, bad voice acting, plot so basic that it might not exist... yeah, I can't fault this game for being as basic and bad as it is since 1992 and all, but there's no reason to buy it.\nI never played this one myself so that could be part of it? But even then there's so little there.

reviewText:
I recently bought the Humongous Entertainment pack, so what the heck, might as well review all the games for the benefit of those who (somehow) have never played them.

Out of all of the HE series, I tend to like Putt-Putt the least.  Not because they are bad games, but simply because they are much more kid-oriented than Freddi Fish, Pajama Sam, or Spy Fox.  Unfortunately, Putt-Putt Joins the Parade is no exception.  It really just doesn't have that much to it.  You do mindless chores to earn money so that you can join the parade.  That's basically it.

If you have a small child, they might like it.  Maybe.  Other than that, there's really no reason to pick this one up.  Almost every Putt-Putt game is better than this one, and almost every HE series is better than Putt-Putt.  So this one sits pretty low in the rankings.

reviewText: Only con is the price, of course people will pay seven dollars for it since one) It's a great game for children and two) it has memories for ourselves; but due to graphics and such I think it should at least be down to five dollars.\n\nNow that that is out of the way, this game is adorable and fun! You can click on just about anything to see a little animation happen, you can mow other peoples' lawns, you can deliver groceries, you can do a lot. There's a fun story, and it CAN be challenging for the little tots, but I think someone who is five or six can figure them out. :) I recommend this game. (Add me on Steam! ThatsPandaGirl )

reviewText:
My life as a car:

Ate cereal and oil
Brushed my teeth
Snooped on the love life of flowers
Honked my horn at a cow
Scared the ♥♥♥♥ out of birds. No birdseed for you
Mowed lawns
Delivered groceries
Recieved a car wash and paint job
Popped my tires
Stole gas and tires
Stole a magnent
Listened to some unfunny animals patranoize my shopping experience
Recieved a balloon from an irresponsible women at a movie theater
Stole an abandoned puppy in an isolated cave
Watched a bunch of cars show off their pets
Popped balloons.

If you've ever wondered what it would be like to live as a car, this is the game for you!

100000/10

reviewText: Like Spy Fox & Pajama Sam, Putt-Putt was alas another computer game series I would of enjoyed had I played it as a kid. Before Pixar made their Cars movies, this was just among the talking car" genre. Putt-Putt is a purple putt-putt car who wants to be part of Car Town's parade that was being held today. In order for Putt-Putt to join he must do various errands to be in top shape and find a balloon and pet dog in order to be qualified. This was the very first Humungous game so it does show it's age as oppose to their later games. The game was intended for young kids so the gameplay isn't that long plus this was their first attempt to create a computer game so give them mercy as their later games do get better. This game is worth buying for your kids and also only worth playing for die hard Humungous Game fans."

reviewText: Childhood nostalgia!  This along with Freddie the Fish was what I grew up on, and if I ever have kids, I hope this is the first game I introduce him or her to.\n\nOne tip is that you need to press F5 to bring up the menu options to close out of the game, or you can beat the game (~15 or so minutes if you rush through it) and click the no face, and it will close out by itself.  I'm sure on Windows you can Alt-Tab out of it, but it doesn't work on Linux (at least on my distribution), so you need to press F5 to exit the game.
